item.title: Social care reform plans facing Tory tax backlash
item.description: The PM is in talks on how to fund changes, but Conservative MPs warn against a National Insurance hike.

item.title: Afghanistan: Minister apologises over 'inaccurate' veteran suicide claim
item.description: James Heappey corrects himself after mistakenly saying a British Afghan veteran had taken their own life.

item.title: Afghanistan: Boris Johnson to face MPs over handling of crisis
item.description: Boris Johnson will vow to to use "every economic, political and diplomatic lever" to help Afghans.

item.title: Twins conjoined at head separated after rare surgery in Israel
item.description: The one-year-old girls are said to be recovering well after the 12-hour operation in Israel.

item.title: Covid: Social care plans and schools return amid virus fears
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Monday morning.

item.title: Sarah Harding: Nadine Coyle and Nicola Roberts lead tributes
item.description: The singer died from cancer on Sunday aged 39, her mother confirmed on Instagram.

item.title: Frozen eggs and sperm storage limit increased to 55 years
item.description: The health secretary says it "will help turn off the ticking clock in the back of people's minds".

item.title: NI Protocol: Further delay expected for Irish Sea border checks
item.description: An EU source says an announcement on grace periods for some products is expected as early as Tuesday.

item.title: Reports of sex abuse between children double in two years
item.description: Reports of children sexually abusing other children double in two years, BBC Panorama finds.

item.title: Claudia Lawrence's mum says she has 'no hope' for new leads
item.description: Joan Lawrence says she cannot 'live in hope' that new leads will mean her daughter is found.

item.title: Australian boy, 3, rescued after four days lost in bush
item.description: Anthony "AJ" Elfalak was spotted by a helicopter, drinking water from a creek near his home.

item.title: Afghanistan: Rural areas welcome peace and end of war
item.description: In more rural areas of Afghanistan, people welcome the end of a war that has killed tens of thousands.

item.title: Students return with school restrictions lifted
item.description: Students across the UK are returning to school after the summer break and and a year disrupted by Covid.

item.title: The Papers: PM faces tax plan 'mutiny', and Harding tributes
item.description: Dominating Monday's papers are Boris Johnson's expected plans to raise National Insurance contributions.

item.title: Spider season: Why your home might feel full of arachnids right now
item.description: They're not coming through the windows - they were already inside.

item.title: Black interns: 'You just need to give us a chance'
item.description: Young black university students are being invited to apply for 2,000 internships at top companies.

item.title: Back to school: How are pupils being kept Covid-safe?
item.description: Many children are returning to school after the holidays, while Scottish pupils already returned.

item.title: Saving Australian frog species on the brink of extinction
item.description: Scientists fear four species are already extinct but say urgent action can save others.

item.title: South Africa danger zone: Living in a 'hijacked' building
item.description: Pictures of squatters in a South African inner city with high levels of crime, drugs and prostitution.

item.title: Khalid Sheikh Mohammed: How '9/11 mastermind' slipped through FBI's fingers
item.description: Could the man accused of hatching the plot to fly planes into US landmarks 20 years ago have been stopped?

item.title: Sarah Harding: She was always going at 100mph
item.description: The team behind Girls Aloud's biggest hits remember Sarah Harding who's died at the age of 39.

item.title: Feria: Rural memoirs stir longing for Spain's past
item.description: Ana Iris Simón's autobiographical book triggers a frenzied debate about the loss of village life.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Joe Ferrari: The high-rolling life of Thailand's controversial ex-police chief
item.description: Joe Ferrari, who is said to own 42 cars, was last month pictured torturing a suspect to death.

item.title: Has Covid killed off business cards for good?
item.description: Sales of business cards have fallen sharply as a result of the pandemic.

item.title: Paralympics: ‘We the disabled community are here to stay’
item.description: Four champions share their glory and their pain from the 16th Paralympic Games in Tokyo.

item.title: England can chase record target to beat India - Woakes
item.description: England can draw on recent experiences of extraordinary run chases in their bid to win the fourth Test against India, according to all-rounder Chris Woakes.

item.title: Brazil v Argentina abandoned after visiting players accused of Covid violation
item.description: Brazil and Argentina's World Cup qualifier is abandoned after Brazilian health officials walked onto the pitch minutes after kick off to object to the participation of three Argentine players.

item.title: Child food poverty 'devastatingly' worse - Rashford
item.description: The footballer urges people to write to their MP as a survey indicates food poverty is worsening.

item.title: Europe lead US going into Solheim Cup final singles
item.description: Europe hold off a United States fight back to take a 9-7 lead into Monday's Solheim Cup singles matches in Ohio.

item.title: US Senator Lindsey Graham: 'We will be going back into Afghanistan'
item.description: Republican Senator Lindsey Graham believes there will be no choice as "the threat will be so large".

item.title: Afghanistan: Taliban accused of killing pregnant police officer
item.description: The killing comes amid increasing reports of escalating repression of women in Afghanistan.

item.title: Afghanistan: What's life like since the Taliban took over?
item.description: People around the country tell the BBC they have lost basic freedoms and are struggling to survive.

item.title: Afghanistan: Despair of Brits and UK allies stuck behind Taliban lines
item.description: An NHS worker, a teacher and families trapped in Afghanistan tell the BBC about their plans now.

item.title: Afghanistan women's cricket team: Players hiding in Kabul fear Taliban rule
item.description: Members of Afghanistan's women's cricket team are hiding in Kabul, fearing for their safety following the Taliban's return to power.

item.title: British soldier describes caring for Kabul airport baby
item.description: Lt Col Ben Caesar helped look after the baby who was pulled over the airport wall in Afghanistan.

item.title: Life under the Taliban: Where is your male escort?
item.description: Lyse Doucet takes the temperature on the streets of the Afghan capital as the Taliban tighten their grip.

item.title: Kabul drone strike: The key questions about a US attack
item.description: Ten Afghan civilians died when the US targeted a vehicle it says was linked to an imminent bombing.

item.title: Afghanistan: Taliban parade captured equipment in Kandahar
item.description: The militant group showcased the kit captured during their takeover of Afghanistan.

item.title: Tanni Grey-Thompson column: 'Great moments in Tokyo but Para-sport faces challenges'
item.description: Baroness Tanni Grey-Thompson reflects on Great Britain's performance at the Tokyo Paralympics and what comes next for Para-sport.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Memorable moments from the Games
item.description: BBC Sport looks back at 10 memorable moments from the Tokyo Paralympic Games.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Great Britain finish Games with two more bronze medals
item.description: Great Britain win two bronze medals on the final day of the Tokyo Paralympics to finish second in the medal table.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics medal table - which country won most golds?
item.description: Which country topped the medal table at the Tokyo 2020 Paralympics? How did Great Britain get on?

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Who are Great Britain's medal winners?
item.description: A list of the Great Britain medal winners from the Tokyo 2020 Paralympics.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Hannah Cockroft & Aled Sion Davies retain titles for GB
item.description: British athletes Hannah Cockroft and Aled Sion Davies retain their Paralympic titles, as canoeists Charlotte Henshaw and Laura Sugar also triumph on day 11 in Tokyo.

item.title: Tokyo 2020: The Paralympic dream that started at the supermarket
item.description: Aruba had never had a Paralympic team until a student in her 20s decided to make it happen.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: What you need to know about Paralympic classification
item.description: From KL1 to PT2 and F11 to SB6 - everything you need to know about classification at the Paralympic Games.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Great Britain win three golds and pass 100-medal mark
item.description: Great Britain win three more golds on day 10 and pass the 100-medal mark at the Tokyo Paralympics.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Sport-by-sport guide
item.description: Twenty-two sports will feature in the Tokyo Paralympics - find out more about them all here.

item.title: Sarah Storey says her 17th Paralympic gold 'feels like an out of body experience'
item.description: Britain's Sarah Storey says she "feels immensely proud" to have won a record 17 Paralympic gold medals and is hoping to add more at Paris 2024.

item.title: Shot putter stripped of gold - for being three minutes late
item.description: Muhammad Ziyad Zolkefli won his shot put event but had his title revoked because he was three minutes late.

item.title: Tokyo Paralympics: Afghanistan athlete Hossain Rasouli makes debut after evacuation
item.description: Afghanistan evacuee Hossain Rasouli finally gets his chance to compete at the Tokyo Paralympics - and his opponents can't "help but feel joy".

item.title: The hard men removing squatters in Spain
item.description: Some squatters in Spain demand cash before leaving - so eviction firms have arisen to handle the talks.

item.title: Afghanistan: Shukria Barakzai's whispered voice notes and dramatic escape
item.description: The desperate messages sent by Afghan politician Shukria Barakzai to a UK MP as the Taliban tried to hunt her down.

item.title: Afghanistan: The 'undefeated' Panjshir Valley - an hour from Kabul
item.description: The Panjshir Valley has been a flashpoint in Afghanistan's turbulent history - now it's happening again.

item.title: Bilal Sarwary: 'The plane hit the tower and all our lives changed'
item.description: Afghan journalist Bilal Sarwary was selling carpets when 9/11 happened. From that day on, everything changed.

item.title: Shot in the head in Angola, left for dead, now a Wetherspoons star
item.description: Cesar Kimbirima fled Angola after being shot four times and spending five months in a coma.
